user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following MHD_lookup_header_token_ci code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 8.13.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of MHD_lookup_header_token_ci.
```c
static bool
MHD_lookup_header_token_ci (const struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            const char *header,
                            size_t header_len,
                            const char *token,
                            size_t token_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  if ((NULL == connection) || (NULL == header) || (0 == header[0]) ||
      (NULL == token) || (0 == token[0]))
    return false;

  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if ((0 != (pos->kind & MHD_HEADER_KIND)) &&
        (header_len == pos->header_size) &&
        ( (header == pos->header) ||
          (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (header,
                                          pos->header,
                                          header_len)) ) &&
        (MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (pos->value, token, token_len)))
      return true;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The struct member pos->value is used only for read-only string operations but appears to be a non-const pointer (e.g. char *). Passing it to a caseless-search function that takes a const char * shows that the member should have been declared const char * (or pos should be a pointer-to-const header). Therefore the pointer in the data structure is not const-qualified where it could be — a violation of Rule 8.13.
</scenario>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: Not enough evidence to declare a MISRA 8.13 violation. The claim hinges on the declaration of struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header (in particular the type of pos->value) and on whether pos->value is modified anywhere else. The snippet shows only read-only uses of pos->value (passed to a function taking const char *), but that alone does not prove the member could not legitimately be a non-const pointer (it may be modified elsewhere, or the struct may be part of APIs that require mutability). MISRA 8.13 requires a pointer to be const-qualified whenever possible across the whole program; determining that “possible” requires inspecting the struct definition and all uses, not just this single function. Therefore the report is not provably correct from the information given.
